thread.title: 'Gold Rush' Preview predicts an exciting Season 6
thread.title_full: 'Gold Rush' Preview predicts an exciting Season 6 | Examiner.com

author: Barbie Crafts
title: 'Gold Rush' Preview predicts an exciting Season 6
text:
Play Gold Rush returns for an all new season Fri Oct 16 at 9/8c. on.aol.com Discovery Channel treated Sunday night viewers of " Alaska : The Last Frontier" to a preview of the upcoming new season of "Gold Rush. " There is a two-hour season premier scheduled for Friday, Oct. 16, at 9 p.m. with an hour-long pre-show, "The Dirt", at 8 p.m. " Gold Rush " has long been the top-rated non-scripted programming on cable television. As Season 6 begins, viewers are waiting to hear what will happen to their favorite, almost cartoon-like characters.
The preview was a much-abbreviated presentation, but it did tease us with a bit of information about what to look for in the new season. The most shocking news on this short glimpse of the future was the sight of Parker Schnabel's right-hand man, Gene, working for someone else. To top it off, that someone was Parker's nemesis claim owner, Tony Beets! Gene was shown operating Beets’ newly-reconstructed, 70-year-old dredge. Beets was also shown throwing Parker off of the claim, much to Parker’s disbelief. He asked Tony Beets how many times before he had thrown him off.
The Hoffmans have a lot to prove this season as Todd’s teenage son joins the operation. Oddly, Todd’s top competitor, Parker Schnabel, is merely a few years older than his young son, and that has to be a slap in the face. Family becomes even more important to the Beets family, too, as they were shown pulling together to make the ancient dredge become productive once again. Speaking of family, viewers have also wondered about the condition of Parker Schnabel’s grandpa over the off-season. He is apparently still around, at least at the time of filming, and still giving sound advice to his grandson, according to this short clip. (In his 90s, he is battling cancer with amazing personal determination.) This was good to know because the audience has fallen in love with this sprite, lively man.
The Washington Post wrote on Monday, "'Gold Rush' works because it's not about gold, it's about humanity." This is so very true. The “Gold Rush” season premiere just can’t get here soon enough.
